utterances: Can this body, the OAS, do anything meaningful to change this though?
Well, it's unclear what's going to happen now.
The current president needs to hand over the powers in the middle of next month.
So that's very short term to hold a new election.

And Salvador Nasralla has long said, and he told us in an interview in Honduras just last week, that he would not allow for an election to be done over with the current electoral body governing that election.
He wants international observers to hold that election.
So that would take a lot of time and preparation to pull that off.
How much fear is there of instability and potentially more protests and violence in that country?
Well, overnight, roads were blocked and there were street protests held again.
Nasralla, who's on his way to Washington to meet with the OAS and U.S.
officials, he's not even in Honduras, he had a stopover in Miami and he went on Facebook from the airport decrying the decision and urging people to stand up and to continue fighting.
And then his ally, the former president, Manuel Zelaya, read a statement urging people to the streets.
And he also made the stunning declaration where he urged the armed forces and the police to only take orders from Salvador Nasralla and not the current president and not to repress the people.
Wow, OK, we'll have to see where this goes in Honduras.
And NPR's Carrie Kahn in Mexico City, we hope you feel better, Carrie.
Thanks.
Thank you.
Some people may wonder what family conflicts at the holidays do to their blood pressure.
There's new guidance as to what counts as high blood pressure so it is important if you're measuring your blood pressure to get an accurate reading, which is surprisingly hard.
NPR's Richard Harris reports that people who administer the test often do it wrong.
Pilots run through a long checklist of safety checks before they're allowed to take off, notes Dr. Paul Whelton at Tulane University.
And we would be shocked if a pilot told us he knew we were in a rush and he was busy and just didn't have time to do it.
Unfortunately, he says, that's too often the case in busy medical offices when it comes to measuring blood pressure accurately.
So Whelton and his colleagues, who developed the new blood pressure standards, also included a checklist of do's and don'ts for measuring it.
We ran down the rules at a medical office, appropriately enough, not far from Dulles International Airport near Washington, D.C.
I'm going to bring you folks on down here to Room 2.
Medical assistant Emily Blair leads a client, Mary Ann Henderson, down the hall.
Before you get seated, I'm actually going to go ahead and get your weight.
I wouldn't have had a big breakfast.
(LAUGHTER)
With that done, Blair steers her client away from the exam table, which is on the do-not list of places to have your blood pressure taken.
If you are lying flat or your legs are dangling that can foul up the reading.
And if you would like to have a seat over here in one of these chairs.
Blair asks Henderson to put her feet flat on the ground and to uncross her legs, more steps on the checklist.
I'm just going to go ahead and get back into your chart, and we're just going to update some information.
OK.
Senior news analyst Daniel Schorr has some ideas.
To the people on the ground in places like Marjah, they think that means everybody's going home next summer.

And so, those who are supportive of the government or those who would like to be supportive of the government have this great fear that they will be once abandoned by the United States and its NATO allies.
Rajiv Chandrasekaran of the Washington Post, thank you very much.
Great to talk to you.
Having received those congratulatory phone calls from both Obama and Clinton, Senator John McCain heads to Washington today, where he'll get a show of support from President Bush.
McCain swept all four Republican primaries yesterday, winning enough delegates to guarantee his nomination, as NPR's Scott Horsley reports.
John McCain supporters didn't have long to savor the balloon drop last night.

McCain said he was pleased to have the nomination in hand, but added now comes the most important part of the campaign - making a respectful but convincing case that he and not Barack Obama or Hillary Clinton should be the next president.
So stand up with me, my friends.
Stand up and fight for America - for her strength, her ideals, and her future.
The contest begins tonight.
(Soundbite of cheering, applause)
McCain says he's ready to challenge the Democrats on issues of trade, health care, and especially the war in Iraq.
His steadfast defense of the war and the troop surge nearly sank his campaign last summer.
But Middletown, Ohio, housewife Phyllis Henry says she's glad McCain stuck to his guns.
He has the courage to stand by his convictions.
To me, that's one of the best qualities of any leader - not to stick their finger in the wind and say, well, maybe I better say this this week and something else the next week.
He's not going to do that.
Henry calls herself a moderate Republican, and says she's proud that her candidate got the party's nod.
McCain had trouble early on winning more conservative voters.
But he is making gains with the party's right wing.
Retired Texas insurance man Mark Herman says he and his fellow conservatives will fall in line.
What choice does a conservative have?
Obama, who's a socialist?
Or Hillary?
Or McCain?
There's no choice.
Now we'll fight among ourselves to get it settled.
And after the dust settles down and our a national primaries come, they're going to vote for McCain.
What little dust was left in the GOP settled last night, after McCain swept all four Republican primaries.
Former Arkansas Governor Mike Huckabee dropped out of the race, after a congratulatory call to McCain.

I extended to him not only my congratulations, but my commitment to him and to the party to do everything possible to unite our party, but more importantly to unite our country, so that we can be the best nation we can be.
McCain's lock on the nomination caps a stunning comeback.
The candidate was all but written off last summer, but McCain persevered, driving his Straight Talk Express bus to more than l00 town hall meetings in New Hampshire alone.
He promises to keep that up in the general election.
I'll travel across the country in cities and rural areas, in communities of all ethnic backgrounds and income levels, offering my ideas and listening to the concerns and advice of Americans.
McCain still faces big challenges.
Political analyst Jack Pitney of Claremont McKenna College says chief among those is the sagging economy, which exit polls showed the economy to be the number one concern in Ohio and Texas.
History of American elections is very clear: The electorate punishes the party in power when there's a recession.
So if you really want to predict the outcome of the election, don't look on the political page.
Look on the business page.
With almost two out of three Americans saying the country is on the wrong track, McCain is defending the president's tax cuts, the similar approach to health care and a still unpopular war.
Advisers say McCain will make it clear he's not a carbon copy of President Bush, but that will have to wait until after the two men share a private lunch at the White House today.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Dallas.
You can find state-by-state results and more analysis from yesterday's primaries by visiting npr.org/elections.
Our business news starts with a bid against Pop-Tarts from the company that makes them.
This morning the world's largest cereal maker unveiled the plan to phase out advertising unhealthy food to kids.
Kellogg Company plans to stop marketing cereals like Froot Loops and Apple Jacks to children under 12 unless those products can meet new nutritional guidelines.
The changes come after advocacy groups and parents threatened to sue Kellogg for marketing junk food to kids.
The groups have now agreed not to proceed with the lawsuit.
Kellogg says half of the products it markets to kids don't make the nutritional cut.
From NPR News, it's All Things Considered.
I'm Robert Siegel.
A photograph of President Obama taken today in the Oval Office reveals a nearly empty desk.
But Mr. Obama's first full day as president was a busy one.
It included issuing an executive order that sets new ethics rules regarding his staff's dealings with lobbyists.
He met with military advisers, and he made phone calls to leaders in the Middle East.
As NPR's Don Gonyea reports, the day began with prayer.

After a long historic inauguration day and night, President Barack Obama was at the National Cathedral this morning participating in a Washington tradition dating back to George Washington, the presidential inaugural prayer service.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG ""HE'S GOT THE WHOLE WORLD IN HIS HANDS"")
(Singing) He's got the whole world in his hands, He's got the whole world...
